facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 781 to 784 of 1963 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 781 to 784 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated March 17, 1961 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Orders Nos. 212, 433, 435 and 436 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated March 17, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original orders Nos. 212, 433, 435 and 436 of 1959 respectively.

facts.text: Appeals before Supreme Court by certificates granted by High Court under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are before us by virtue of certificates granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution

facts.text: Zamindar of Simlapal in Bankura entered into contract with appellant Ram Krissen Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Zamindar of Simlapal in the Collectorate of Bankura entered into a companytract with the appellant Ram Krissen Singh

facts.text: By document dated September 3, 1946, Zamindar granted appellant right to cut trees in demarcated areas of forests for Rs. 7,131/8/- .

anchor.surface_text: and by a document dated September 3, 1946, granted him the right to cut the trees, in certain demarcated areas, of certain forests of the Zamindari on payment of a sum of Rs. 7,131/8/- .

facts.text: Period of right to cut trees under the document ends on April 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the said document the period during which the appellant was given this right to cut trees was to end on April 14, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant started cutting operations but cut only for the first few years.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant started the cutting operations and cut only for, the first few years,

facts.text: Forest Officers of the State prevented appellant from further cutting under West Bengal Private Forests Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: but thereafter action was taken by the Forest Officers of the State to prevent him from further cutting under the powers vested in them by the West Bengal Private Forests Act, 1948.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 for writ of certiorari to quash orders and injunction against Forest Officers.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the appellant tiled a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ of certiorari for quashing the orders passed against him and also for an injunction restraining the Forest Officers from taking delivery of possession and from cutting and disposing of the forests companyered by his agreement.

facts.text: West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953 (Act 1 of 1954) had been passed by time of writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: By the time the petition was filed the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953  Act 1 of 1954 ,  hereafter referred to as the Act  had been passed

facts.text: Counter-affidavit in writ petition claimed estate and rights to trees vested in State under S.5 by notification under S.4.

anchor.surface_text: and in the companynter-affidavit which was filed to this petition reliance was placed upon its provisions for companytending that the estate belonging to the Zamindar in which the forest lay as well as all the rights to the trees therein, to whomsoever belonging, had vested in the State -under S. 5 of the Act by reason of a numberification issued by the State Government under s. 4.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court decisions held S.5 did not include right to cut trees granted to third person before vesting.

anchor.surface_text: By the date the writ petition came to be heard the West Bengal Legislature had, in view of certain decisions rendered by the Calcutta High Court which held that the terms of s. 5 of the Act which specified the property or interest in property which would vest in the Government did number include the right to cut trees in a forest, which had been granted to a third person by the proprietor or intermediary before the date of the vesting,

facts.text: West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act amended by introducing S.5(aa) with retrospective effect from commencement of principal Act.

anchor.surface_text: amended the said vesting section by introducing S. 5  aa  to have retrospective effect from the date of the companymencement of the principal Act.

facts.text: Amendment by West Bengal Act 25 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5  aa  read Upon the due publication of a numberification under section 4,

facts.text: Petitioner amended writ petition adding allegations on construction and constitutional validity of S.5(aa).

anchor.surface_text: After this amendment was brought to the numberice of the Court the petitioner was allowed to amend -his writ petition by adding allegations  a  regarding the companystruction of the said section, and   b  its companystitutional validity.

facts.text: Writ petition heard in December 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The petition then came on for hearing in December, 1958,

facts.text: Single Judge discharged rule by judgment dated December 24, 1958 following earlier decisions.

anchor.surface_text: and the learned Single Judge, by his judgment dated December 24, 1958 discharged the rule followcertain earlier decisions of his on the same point.

facts.text: Letters Patent appeal to Division Bench dismissed but certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) granted.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal filed to the Division Bench under the Letters Patent was also dismissed but the learned Judges granted a certificate under Art. 133 1   c  and that is how the appeal is before us.

facts.text: Amendment of S.5 by adding cl.(aa) necessitated by Calcutta High Court decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The amendment effected by the addition of cl.  aa  to s. 5 was admittedly necessitated by certain decisions of the High Court of Calcutta which held that where an intermediary had granted a right to cut trees or to forest produce, the rights so companyferred were unaffected by the vesting provision in s. 5 of the Act as it stood before the amendment.

facts.text: West Bengal Act 1 of 1954 included in Ninth Schedule by 17th Amendment to Constitution.

facts.text: Relevant facts in four appeals are analogous.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts in these four appeals are analogous and they raise the companymon question of law which we have already indicated.

issues.text: the question of the proper construction of S. 5(aa) of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953 (West Bengal Act 1 of 1954) as amended by West Bengal Act 25 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are before us by virtue of certificates granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution and they raise for companysideration the question of the proper companystruction of S. 5 aa  of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953  West Bengal Act 1 of 1954  as amended by West Bengal Act 25 of 1957.

issues.text: whether the terms of s. 5(aa) are sufficient and apt to provide for the vesting of the right to cut the trees when such right belonged, on the date of the vesting, not to the intermediary or Zamindar but to another person to whom it had been granted under a contract with the said intermediary

anchor.surface_text: The first, and possibly the only, question that number calls for companysideration is whether the terms of s. 5  aa  are sufficient and apt to provide for the vesting of the right to cut the trees when such right belonged, on the date of the vesting, number to the intermediary or Zamindar but to another person to whom it had been granted under a companytract with the said intermediary.

issues.text: whether the use of the words 'together with' in s. 5(aa) requires that the right to the trees constituted an integral part of the right to the land by way of common ownership

anchor.surface_text: Taking up, first, the word together with the submission was that it was only where the right to the trees companystituted an integral part of the right to the land that a vesting was effected of the latter right and that where there had been a severance of the two rights it was only the land that remained in the intermediary that became vested and number the right to the tree,-,.

issues.text: whether the words 'held by an intermediary or any other person' in s. 5(aa) require that both the land and the right to the trees inhere in the intermediary

anchor.surface_text: Coming next to the words and held by an intermediary learned companynsel companyld number justifiably submit an argument that both the land and the right to the trees should inhere in the intermediary to attract the operation of the clause, because the words held by an intermediary are followed by any other person.

issues.text: whether, given the scheme of the Act provides compensation for every interest acquired and there is no provision for compensating interests of persons like the appellant, such interest was within the vesting provision of s. 5(aa)

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee next submitted that the scheme of the Act was the provision of companypensation for every interest acquired by the State by virtue of the vesting under s. 5 and that as there was numberprovision in the Act for companypensating the interest of persons like the appellant, the Court should hold that such. an interest was number within the vesting section-,-,. 5  aa .

anchor.surface_text: A further point that was urged before the High Court was that the enactment was unconstitutional in that numberprovision was made for the award of companypensation to persons in the position of the appellant whose rights to cut trees became vested in the State.

holdings.text: the terms of s. 5 aa are sufficient and apt to provide for the vesting of the right to cut the trees when such right belonged, on the date of the vesting, not to the intermediary or Zamindar but to another person to whom it had been granted under a contract with the said intermediary

anchor.surface_text: The first, and possibly the only, question that calls for consideration is whether the terms of s. 5  aa  are sufficient and apt to provide for the vesting of the right to cut the trees when such right belonged, on the date of the vesting, not to the intermediary or Zamindar but to another person to whom it had been granted under a contract with the said intermediary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain words vest severed third-party rights; rejects petitioner's textual arguments on 'together with' and 'held by'; legislative purpose to overcome High Court decisions confirms

holdings.text: the expression together is obviously used to denote not the necessity for integrality between the land and the right to cut trees by way of common ownership but as merely an enumeration of the items of property which vest in the State. In the context, the word means no more than the expression as well as and imports no condition that the right to the trees should also belong to the owner of the land

anchor.surface_text: Taking up, first, the word together with the submission was that it was only where the right to the trees constituted an integral part of the right to the land that a vesting was effected of the latter right and that where there had been a severance of the two rights it was only the land that remained in the intermediary that became vested and not the right to the tree,-,. We feel unable to accept this argument. We consider that the expression together is obviously used to denote not the necessity for integrality between the land and the right to cut trees by way of common ownership but as merely an enumeration of the items of property which vest in the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Together with' denotes enumeration ('as well as'), not common ownership; disjunctive 'or to the produce thereof' confirms independent vesting of tree/produce rights

holdings.text: the words held by an intermediary or any other person [...] apply equally to cases where the land belongs to an intermediary and the right to the trees or to the produce of the trees to another person

anchor.surface_text: Coming next to the words and held by an intermediary learned counsel could not justifiably submit an argument that both the land and the right to the trees should inhere in the intermediary to attract the operation of the clause, because the words held by an intermediary are followed by any other person. Obviously, that other person i.e., person other than the intermediary, could have the right either to the land, a right to the trees or a right to the produce.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Or any other person' explicitly covers third parties holding tree or produce rights independently of land ownership

holdings.text: in view of the plain words of S. 5 aa which we have discussed earlier, we do not find it possible to accept the argument [that absence of compensation provision means interest not within vesting section]

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee next submitted that the scheme of the Act was the provision of compensation for every interest acquired by the State by virtue of the vesting under s. 5 and that as there was no provision in the Act for compensating the interest of persons like the appellant, the Court should hold that such an interest was not within the vesting section- s. 5 aa . This is, of course, a legitimate argument, and if there had been any ambiguity in the construction of s. 5 aa , the circumstance referred to by learned counsel would certainly have great weight. But in view of the plain words of S. 5 aa which we have discussed earlier, we do not find it possible to accept the argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme argument legitimate only if ambiguity, but plain words preclude; absence affects constitutionality, not construction

holdings.text: this question about the constitutional validity of the amending Act does not really fall for consideration because learned counsel for the appellant did not contest the position that after the enactment of the 17th Amendment to the Constitution, and the inclusion of West Bengal Act 1 of 1954 among those specified in Schedule IX, the absence of a provision for compensation [...] would not render the West Bengal Act or the acquisition thereunder unconstitutional
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not contested post-17th Amendment placing Act in Ninth Schedule immunizing from challenge

anchor.surface_text: We feel unable to accept this argument.

anchor.surface_text: Taking up, first, the word together with the submission was that it was only where the right to the trees constituted an integral part of the right to the land that a vesting was effected of the latter right and that where there had been a severance of the two rights it was only the land that remained in the intermediary that became vested and not the right to the tree,-,. We feel unable to accept this argument. We consider that the expression together is obviously used to denote not the necessity for integrality between the land and the right to cut trees by way of common ownership but as merely an enumeration of the items of property which vest in the State.
We feel unable to accept this argument.

edges.explanation: Holding on third-party application contributes to sufficiency for vesting

anchor.surface_text: right to the trees in that land. Besides, it is number possible to read the words held by an intermediary or any other person to mean that they are ap

edges.explanation: Holding on words applying to third-party tree rights addresses issue of required inherence in intermediary

anchor.surface_text: Coming next to the words and held by an intermediary learned counsel could not justifiably submit an argument that both the land and the right to the trees should inhere in the intermediary to attract the operation of the clause, because the words held by an intermediary are followed by any other person. Obviously, that other person i.e., person other than the intermediary, could have the right either to the land, a right to the trees or a right to the produce.
We feel unable to accept this argument.
d under the original enactment is number an irrelevant factor to be taken into account. Mr. Chatterjee next submitted that the scheme of the Act was t

edges.explanation: Holding rejects the argument in the issue regarding absence of compensation provision under the Act's scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee next submitted that the scheme of the Act was the provision of compensation for every interest acquired by the State by virtue of the vesting under s. 5 and that as there was no provision in the Act for compensating the interest of persons like the appellant, the Court should hold that such an interest was not within the vesting section- s. 5 aa . This is, of course, a legitimate argument, and if there had been any ambiguity in the construction of s. 5 aa , the circumstance referred to by learned counsel would certainly have great weight. But in view of the plain words of S. 5 aa which we have discussed earlier, we do not find it possible to accept the argument.
We feel unable to accept this argument.
